title: Warren Fends Off Party Challenger in Massachusetts Race
content:
After the event , the Brown campaign held a news conference in the rainy square across the street from the cavernous convention hall . Peter Blute , a Republican and former congressman , said that Ms. Warren had “ snuffed out ” her opponent . The lopsided victory , he said , was “ the very thorough slap-down of a candidate. ” He said he expected questions about her ancestry to dog her because she had shown a “ pattern ” of lacking credibility .
Ms. Warren had begun the day with some good news , with two new polls — by The Boston Globe and Western New England University — showing her running essentially even with Mr. Brown .

View all New York Times newsletters .
In a feisty speech to the delegates before the vote , she invoked the spirit of Senator Edward M. Kennedy , who is still lionized by activists here and whose death in 2009 led to the special election in which Mr. Brown captured the seat .
“ It ’ s a long way from Ted Kennedy to Scott Brown , ” Ms. Warren said .
She also dismissed the controversy in which her campaign has been mired for more than a month — whether she had unfairly claimed American Indian ancestry to advance her academic career .
“ If that ’ s all you ’ ve got , Scott Brown , I ’ m ready , ” she declared to the cheering crowd . “ And let me be clear . I am not backing down . I didn ’ t get in this race to fold up the first time I got punched . ”
“ I ’ m ready , ” Ms. Warren repeated to the delegates after the vote was announced . She asked them if they were also ready — to take on Wall Street , big oil and to “ stop the Republicans from taking over the United States Senate. ” A huge cheer went up in the hall .
In recent days , Ms. Warren has taken more aggressive steps to try to counteract the fallout from the ancestry issue and criticism of her campaign for failing to respond to the controversy more quickly and fully . Governor Patrick , one of the state ’ s most popular politicians , broke his pledge to stay neutral in the Democratic contest and endorsed her a few days ago .
She also began reaching out to individual reporters . And , she began showing a new defiance . On Friday night , she made the requisite rounds of preconvention parties here packed with the activists whose enthusiasm she will need to get out the vote in November . “ I don ’ t care what they throw at me , ” Ms. Warren said in a near shout to those gathered in Theodore ’ s blues club . “ I will stand my ground . ”
content_original:
After the event, the Brown campaign held a news conference in the rainy square across the street from the cavernous convention hall. Peter Blute, a Republican and former congressman, said that Ms. Warren had “snuffed out” her opponent. The lopsided victory, he said, was “the very thorough slap-down of a candidate.” He said he expected questions about her ancestry to dog her because she had shown a “pattern” of lacking credibility.

Ms. Warren had begun the day with some good news, with two new polls — by The Boston Globe and Western New England University — showing her running essentially even with Mr. Brown.

In a feisty speech to the delegates before the vote, she invoked the spirit of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who is still lionized by activists here and whose death in 2009 led to the special election in which Mr. Brown captured the seat.

“It’s a long way from Ted Kennedy to Scott Brown,” Ms. Warren said.

She also dismissed the controversy in which her campaign has been mired for more than a month — whether she had unfairly claimed American Indian ancestry to advance her academic career.

“If that’s all you’ve got, Scott Brown, I’m ready,” she declared to the cheering crowd. “And let me be clear. I am not backing down. I didn’t get in this race to fold up the first time I got punched.”

“I’m ready,” Ms. Warren repeated to the delegates after the vote was announced. She asked them if they were also ready — to take on Wall Street, big oil and to “stop the Republicans from taking over the United States Senate.” A huge cheer went up in the hall.

In recent days, Ms. Warren has taken more aggressive steps to try to counteract the fallout from the ancestry issue and criticism of her campaign for failing to respond to the controversy more quickly and fully. Governor Patrick, one of the state’s most popular politicians, broke his pledge to stay neutral in the Democratic contest and endorsed her a few days ago.

She also began reaching out to individual reporters. And, she began showing a new defiance. On Friday night, she made the requisite rounds of preconvention parties here packed with the activists whose enthusiasm she will need to get out the vote in November. “I don’t care what they throw at me,” Ms. Warren said in a near shout to those gathered in Theodore’s blues club. “I will stand my ground.”
